clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of VeinViewer in Cosmetic Dermatology

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to understand the impact of VeinViewer technology during routine cosmetic and dermatologic procedures.

detailed_description.textblock: This study was designed as an observational study to determine if VeinViewer technology helped to improve the efficiency of certain dermatological procedures namely botox injections and schlerotherapy for varicose veins. The device was used to identify veins but clinical decisions were ultimately left the physician.

primary_outcome.measure: Patient perception of the use of the device
primary_outcome.description: Small questionnaires will be used to assess how the patient perceives the use of the device (i.e., did the patient have a positive attitude towards the device?)

secondary_outcome.measure: Physician perception of the use of the device
secondary_outcome.description: Physicians will complete a small questionnaire to understand what their perception of the use of the device to be (i.e, did the physician have a positive attitude towards the device while using it).

other_outcome.measure: Detection of adverse events related to the standard of care procedure
other_outcome.description: VeinViewer may be used to detect adverse events related to the standard of care procedure (e.g., bruising).

arm_group.description: VeinViewer will be used in conjunction with routine cosmetic dermatology procedures. Patients and physicians will complete questionnaires.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years of age and up
- Male or Female
- Receiving cosmetic dermatological injection
- Willing to participate
Exclusion Criteria:
- Aged younger than 18 years
- Prior history of known light sensitivity
- Other reasons as determined by investigator
